Show / Hide Table of Contents

Class XmlManager

Provides a high-level object used to manage various aspects of container, query, streaming, context, and transaction management.

Inheritance
System.Object
XmlManager
Implements
System.IDisposable
Inherited Members
System.Object.ToString()
System.Object.Equals(System.Object)
System.Object.Equals(System.Object, System.Object)
System.Object.ReferenceEquals(System.Object, System.Object)
System.Object.GetHashCode()
System.Object.GetType()
System.Object.MemberwiseClone()
Namespace: Figaro
Assembly: Figaro.dll
Syntax
public sealed class XmlManager : IDisposable
Remarks

You use XmlManager to perform activities such as container management (including creation and open), preparing XQuery queries, executing one-off queries, creating transaction objects, creating update and query context objects, and creating input streams.

Constructors

View Source

XmlManager()

Initializes a new instance of the XmlManager class.

Declaration
public XmlManager()
View Source

XmlManager(FigaroEnv)

Initializes a new instance of the XmlManager class that uses the provided FigaroEnv instance for the underlying environment. The subsystems initiated in this environment (for example, transactions, logging, the memory pool), are the subsystems that are available to Figaro when operations are performed using this manager object.

No flags are passed to XmlManager.

Declaration
public XmlManager(FigaroEnv env)
Parameters
Type Name Description
FigaroEnv env

The FigaroEnv to use for the underlying database environment. The environment provided here must be opened.
Remarks

The FigaroEnv must be opened before assigning to the XmlManager constructor.

See Also
EnvOpenOptions
FigaroEnv
View Source

XmlManager(FigaroEnv, ManagerInitOptions)

Initializes a new instance of the XmlManager class. This constructor uses the provided FigaroEnv for the underlying environment. The Figaro subsystems initiated by this environment (for example, transactions, logging, the memory pool), are the subsystems that are available to Figaro when operations are performed using this manager object.

Declaration
public XmlManager(FigaroEnv env, ManagerInitOptions managerInitOptions)
Parameters
Type Name Description
FigaroEnv env

The FigaroEnv to use for the underlying database environment. The environment provided here must be opened.
ManagerInitOptions managerInitOptions

Flags for opening the XmlManager.
Remarks

The FigaroEnv must be opened before assigning to the XmlManager constructor.

See Also
EnvOpenOptions
FigaroEnv
View Source

XmlManager(ManagerInitOptions)

Initializes a new instance of the XmlManager class that uses a private internal database environment.

Declaration
public XmlManager(ManagerInitOptions managerInitOptions)
Parameters
Type Name Description
ManagerInitOptions managerInitOptions

Flags for opening the XmlManager.
Remarks

The underlying FigaroEnv is opened with the Private, Create, and InitMemoryBufferPool flags. These flags allow the underlying environment to be created if it does not already exist. In addition, the memory pool (in-memory cache) is initialized and available. Finally, the environment is private, which means that no external processes can join the environment, but the XmlManager object can be shared between threads within the opening process.

Note that for this form of the constructor, the FigaroEnv home is located in either the current working directory, or in the directory identified by the DB_HOME environment variable.

See Also
EnvOpenOptions
FigaroEnv

DefaultPageSize

Gets or sets the size, in bytes, of the pages used to store documents in the database.

Declaration
public int DefaultPageSize { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
System.Int32

The size, in bytes, of pages used to store documents in the database.
Remarks

The size is specified in bytes in the range 512 bytes to 64K bytes. The system selects a page size based on the underlying file system I/O block size if one is not explicitly set by the application. The default page size has a lower limit of 512 bytes and an upper limit of 16K bytes. Documents that are larger than a single page are stored on multiple pages.

The DefaultPageSize property will only affect containers created after it is set. It has no effect on existing containers.

See Also
XmlManager
Container
View Source

DefaultSequenceIncrement

Gets or sets the integer increment to be used when pre-allocating document IDs for new documents created by PutDocument(String, UpdateContext).

Declaration
public int DefaultSequenceIncrement { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
System.Int32

Gets or sets the number of pre-allocated document IDs for new documents.
Remarks

Every document added to an Container is assigned an internal unique ID, and BDB XML performs an internal database operation to obtain these IDs. In order to increase database concurrency and improve performance of ID allocation, BDB XML pre-allocates a sequence of these numbers. The size of this sequence is determined by the value specified here. The default ID sequence size is 5.

Be aware that when a container is closed, any unused IDs in the current sequence are lost. Under some extreme cases, this can result in a container to which documents can no longer be added. For example, setting this value to a very large number (such as, say, 1 million) and then repeatedly opening and closing the container while adding a few documents will eventually cause the container to run out of IDs. Once out of IDs, the container will never again be able to accept new documents. The maximum number of IDs that a container has available to it is currently 4 billion.

warning

You should almost always leave this value alone. However, if you are loading a large number of documents to a container all at once, you may find a small performance benefit to setting the sequence number to a larger value. If you do this, be aware that this value is persistent across container opens, so you should take care to reset the value to its default once you are done loading the documents.

See Also
XmlManager
Container
View Source

Environment

Gets the underlying FigaroEnv environment object.

Declaration
public FigaroEnv Environment { get; }
Property Value
Type Description
FigaroEnv
Remarks

If a FigaroEnv object is not specified at construction, an internal environment object is created with default settings. This property gives developers access to either the instantiated or default FigaroEnv object associated with this particular XmlManager instance.

This property is only available to Concurrent Data Store (CDS) and Transactional Data Store (TDS) editions of the Figaro XML Database.

See Also
FigaroEnv

AddDataDirectory(String)

Adds a data directory to the XmlManager's environment.

Declaration
public void AddDataDirectory(string dataDirectory)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String dataDirectory

The data directory accessed by the XmlManager.
Remarks

Every XmlManager instance has an FigaroEnv instance associated with it, even if developers do not explicitly associate one to it. This method allows developers to specify one or more data directories for an XmlManager's environment so that developers can reference the container names in XQuery expressions without the need to explicitly provide the absolute path to the container(s) being queried.

See Also
AddDataDirectory(String)
View Source

Declaration

Parameters
Type Name Description
XmlTransaction transaction

If the operation is to be transaction-protected, the parameter is an XmlTransaction handle returned from CreateTransaction().
System.String name

The path and name of the container to compact.
UpdateContext context

The UpdateContext object used for this operation.
Remarks

The container must be closed; the system throws an exception if the container is open.

CreateContainer(XmlTransaction, String)

Creates and opens a container, returning a handle to a Container object using the specified transaction handle. If the container already exists at the time this method is called, an exception is thrown.

Declaration
public Container CreateContainer(XmlTransaction transaction, string name)
Parameters
Type Name Description
XmlTransaction transaction

The XmlTransaction object to use for this container creation.
System.String name

The container's name. The container is created relative to the underlying environment's home directory (see XmlManager for more information) unless an absolute path is used for the name; in that case the container is created in the location identified by the path.

The name provided here must be unique for the environment or an exception is thrown.

Returns
Type Description
Container

A new, opened Container object.
Remarks

Use OpenContainer(String) to open a container that has already been created.

Containers are created by default with the AllowCreate and the ExclusiveCreate flags specified, as well as a NodeContainer storage type.

Containers always remain open until the last handle referencing the container is destroyed.

See Also
OpenContainer(String)
Container

Type Name Description

The container.

The namespace of the node to be used. The default namespace is selected by passing an empty string for the namespace.

The string representing the indexing strategy.
XmlValue value

CreateLocalFileInputStream(String)

Returns an XmlInputStream to the file filename. Use this input stream with PutDocument(String, UpdateContext) or SetContentAsInputStream(XmlInputStream).

Declaration
public XmlInputStream CreateLocalFileInputStream(string fileName)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String fileName

The full path and file name to open with the XmlInputStream.
Returns
Type Description
XmlInputStream

A stream object for Container or XmlDocument to manipulate.
Remarks

If the input stream is passed to either of these methods, it will be adopted, and deleted. If it is not passed, it is the responsibility of the user to delete the object. Note that there is no attempt to ensure that the file referenced contains well-formed or valid XML. Exceptions may be thrown at the time that this input stream is actually read if the stream does not contain well-formed, or valid XML.

See Also
PutDocument(String, UpdateContext)
SetContentAsInputStream(XmlInputStream)

Remarks

If the XmlTransaction object is destroyed or goes out of scope before Commit() or Abort() are called, the state of the underlying transaction is left unchanged. This allows a transaction to be controlled external to its XmlTransaction object.

Prepare(XmlTransaction, String, QueryContext)

Compile an XQuery expression into an XQueryExpression object. You can then run the XQuery expression repeatedly using Execute(QueryContext).

Declaration
public XQueryExpression Prepare(XmlTransaction transaction, string xQuery, QueryContext context)
Parameters
Type Name Description
XmlTransaction transaction

The transaction to execute the preparation under.
System.String xQuery

The XQuery expression to execute.
QueryContext context

The query context to execute under.
Returns
Type Description
XQueryExpression

An XQueryExpression object.
Remarks

Use this method to compile and evaluate XQuery expressions against your Container and XmlDocument objects any time you want to evaluate the expression more than once.

Note that the scope of the query provided here can be restricted using one of the XQuery navigational functions. For example:

collection('mycontainer.dbxml')/foo

or:

doc('dbxml:/mycontainer.dbxml/mydoc.xml')/foo/@attr1='bar'

The scope of a query can also be controlled by passing an appropriate contextItem object to Execute(QueryContext).

See Also
XmlManager
QueryContext
XQueryExpression
XmlTransaction
View Source

Prepare(String, QueryContext)

Compile an XQuery expression into an XQueryExpression object. You can then run the XQuery expression repeatedly using Execute(QueryContext).

public XQueryExpression Prepare(string xQuery, QueryContext context)

The XQuery expression to execute.

Returns
Type Description
XQueryExpression

An XQueryExpression object.
Remarks

Use this method to compile and evaluate XQuery expressions against your Container and XmlDocument objects any time you want to evaluate the expression more than once.

Note that the scope of the query provided here can be restricted using one of the XQuery navigational functions. For example:

collection('mycontainer.dbxml')/foo

or:

doc('dbxml:/mycontainer.dbxml/mydoc.xml')/foo/@attr1='bar'

The scope of a query can also be controlled by passing an appropriate contextItem object to Execute(QueryContext).

See Also

Query(XmlTransaction, String, QueryContext)

Executes a query in the context of the XmlManager object. This method is the equivalent of calling Prepare(String, QueryContext) and then Execute(QueryContext) on the prepared query.

Declaration
public XmlResults Query(XmlTransaction transaction, string xQuery, QueryContext context)
Parameters
Type Name Description
XmlTransaction transaction

The transaction to perform the query with.
System.String xQuery

The XQuery expression to execute.
QueryContext context

The query context to execute under.
Returns
Type Description
XmlResults

An XmlResults object containing the query results.
Remarks

The scope of the query can be restricted using one of the XQuery navigational functions. For example:

collection('mycontainer.dbxml')/foo

or:

doc('dbxml:/mycontainer.dbxml/mydoc.xml')/foo/@attr1='bar'

The scope of a query can also be controlled by passing an appropriate contextItem object to Execute(QueryContext).

Note that this method is suitable for performing one-off queries. If you want to execute a query more than once, you should use Prepare(String, QueryContext) to compile the expression, and then use Execute(QueryContext) to run it.

This method returns an XmlResults object. You then iterate over the results set contained in that object using PreviousDocument() or PreviousValue(), and NextDocument() or NextValue().

For more information on querying containers and documents, see Developing .NET Applications with Figaro.

See Also
XmlManager
XmlResults
QueryContext
@developing-dotnet-apps-with-figaro.md
View Source

Type Description

The scope of the query can be restricted using one of the XQuery navigational functions. For example:

or:

Note that this method is suitable for performing one-off queries. If you want to execute a query more than once, you should use Prepare(String, QueryContext) to compile the expression, and then use Execute(QueryContext) to run it.

This method returns an XmlResults object. You then iterate over the results set contained in that object using NextValue() and PreviousValue().

For more information on querying containers and documents, see Developing .NET Applications with Figaro.

RegisterResolver(XQueryResolver)

Identifies an System.Xml.XmlResolver object to be used for file resolution.

Declaration
public void RegisterResolver(XQueryResolver resolver)
Parameters
Type Name Description
XQueryResolver resolver

The resolver object to register with the XmlManager.
Remarks

This object is used by the internal XML document parser to locate data based on URIs, or public and system ids. Custom System.Xml.XmlResolver objects can be created by applications to provide a mechanism to name and retrieve collections, documents, and XML entities external to the database engine.

View Source

ReindexContainer(XmlTransaction, String, UpdateContext, ReindexOptions)

Re-index an entire container.

Declaration
public void ReindexContainer(XmlTransaction transaction, string name, UpdateContext context, ReindexOptions reindexOptions)
Parameters
Type Name Description
XmlTransaction transaction

The transaction to perform the operation with.
System.String name

The name of the container to perform the re-indexing operation against.
UpdateContext context

The update context to perform the operation with.
ReindexOptions reindexOptions

One or more re-indexing options to use with the operation.
Remarks

The container should be backed up prior to using this method, as it destroys existing indices before re-indexing. If the operation fails, and your container is not backed up, you may lose information.

Use this call to change the type of indexing used for a container between document-level indices and node-level indices. This method can take a very long time to execute, depending on the size of the container, and should not be used casually.

See Also
XmlManager
XmlTransaction
UpdateContext
ReindexOptions
View Source

if the Container is open, or if the container does not exist.

RenameContainer(XmlTransaction, String, String)

Renames the container's underlying file.

Declaration
public void RenameContainer(XmlTransaction transaction, string oldName, string newName)
Parameters
Type Name Description
XmlTransaction transaction

The transaction to perform the operation with.
System.String oldName

The name of the container you are renaming.
System.String newName

The name you are renaming the container to.
Remarks

The container must be closed; the system throws an exception if the container is open.

The container must have been opened at least once; the system throws an exception if the underlying file has not yet been created.

See Also

TruncateContainer(String, UpdateContext)

Truncates all of the databases in the container.

Declaration
public void TruncateContainer(string name, UpdateContext context)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String name

The name of the container to truncate.
UpdateContext context

The context to operate against.
Remarks

If you created a Container object, you must ensure that you run
Close() before attempting to run this method. You must also ensure no other applications are accessing the container when attempting this operation. If either condition exists, an exception will occur. The container must be closed for this operation, or an exception will occur.

See Also
XmlManager
Container
View Source

UpgradeContainer(String, UpdateContext)

Upgrades the underlying Berkeley DB container from a previous version to the current version.

Declaration
public void UpgradeContainer(string name, UpdateContext context)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String name

The name of the container to upgrade.
UpdateContext context

The update context to perform the upgrade against.
Remarks

A Berkeley DB upgrade is first performed, and then the Berkeley DB container is upgraded. If no upgrade is needed, then no changes are made.

warning

Container upgrades are done in place and are destructive. For example, if pages need to be allocated and no disk space is available, the container may be left corrupted. Backups should be made before containers are upgraded. See Upgrading Databases for more information.

The container must be closed; the system throws an exception if the container is open.

See Also
UpdateContext
@upgrading-databases.md
View Source
